mainBoard.name: B.O.B. (Bevy of Beebles)
mainBoard.originalText:
As B.
O.
B. enters the battlefield, create four 1/1 blue Beeble creature tokens.
The number of loyalty counters on B.
O.
B. is equal to the number of Beebles you control. (Create or sacrifice Beebles whenever B.
O.
B. gains or loses loyalty.)
+1: Up to X target Beebles can't be blocked this turn, where X is the number of cards in your hand.
−1: Draw a card.

rulings.text: B.O.B. is not a creature and is not itself a Beeble.
B.O.B.’s loyalty counts all Beebles you control, not just the tokens B.O.B. creates. Or separates? Whatever B.O.B. does.

Conversely, other cards like Primal Vigor don’t mention “effects.” If you control one of these cards, activating B.O.B.’s first loyalty ability would cause you to create two Beebles, and thus put two loyalty counters on B.O.B.

Every time B.O.B loses loyalty, you choose which Beebles to sacrifice. If B.O.B. is dealt more damage than the number of Beebles you control, you sacrifice all of them, and then B.O.B. is put into its owner’s graveyard.
If B.O.B. gains loyalty, the Beeble you create is a 1/1 blue Beeble creature token.

If you control Doubling Season or a similar card that applies “is an effect would create one or more tokens,” you’d create eight Beebles as B.O.B. enters the battlefield. However, because such cards apply only to effects and not costs, you’d still create only one Beeble if you activated B.O.B.’s first loyalty ability.

Sacrificing Beebles to account for B.O.B.’s lost loyalty happens before state-based actions clean up the lethally-damaged Beebles. The one that blocked can heroically be the one you sacrifice. Farewell, brave Beeble. B.O.B.-speed.

mainBoard.text:
As B.O.B. enters, create four 1/1 blue Beeble creature tokens.
The number of loyalty counters on B.O.B. is equal to the number of Beebles you control. (Create or sacrifice Beebles whenever B.O.B. gains or loses loyalty.)
[+1]: Up to X target Beebles can't be blocked this turn, where X is the number of cards in your hand.
[−1]: Draw a card.

mainBoard.name: Alexander Clamilton
mainBoard.originalText:
Whenever you cast a wordy spell, scry 2. (A spell is wordy if it has four or more lines of rules text.)
{1}{R}, {T}: Choose target creature you don't control. Reveal the top card of your library. Alexander Clamilton gets +X/+0 until end of turn, where X is the number of lines of rules text of the revealed card. Alexander Clamilton fights that creature.

rulings.text: Ability words themselves are not rules text, but they’re followed by rules text, so any line with an ability word will count.
Any line with at least one word of rules text counts as a line of rules text.
Its name is Alexander Clamilton.

Some card layouts include rules text in different sections. Count each one separately. For example, “the battlefield” in the “pin-up” section of a host creature is counted separately from the first line of text of that ability’s effect.
There are a million things it hasn’t done, including count reminder text and flavor text. Those aren’t rules text.
This card’s name is Alexander Clamilton.

mainBoard.text:
Whenever you cast a wordy spell, scry 2. (A spell is wordy if it has four or more lines of rules text.)
{1}{R}, {T}: Choose target creature you don't control. Reveal the top card of your library. Alexander Clamilton gets +X/+0 until end of turn, where X is the number of lines of rules text of the revealed card. Alexander Clamilton fights that creature.

mainBoard.name: Avatar of Me
mainBoard.originalText:
This spell costs {1} more to cast for each ten years you've been alive.
Avatar of Me's power is equal to your height in feet and its toughness is equal to your American shoe size. Round to the nearest ½.
Avatar of Me is the color of your eyes.

rulings.text: Avatar of Me is only the color of your eyes, not the color of your eyes and blue. That is, the color it gets from its last ability overrides the blue it gets from its mana cost.
If each of your eyes is a different color (naturally or via a single contact lens), Avatar of Me is both colors.
If you’re wearing colored contact lenses, Avatar of Me is whatever color your eyes appear to be. You can add or remove contact lenses to change your eye color in response to spells and abilities.
Silver-bordered rules include any conceivable eye color, not just the five traditional Magic colors. If your eye are hazel, Avatar of Me is hazel.

Thanks to Avatar of Me, if you’re asked to choose a color in a silver-bordered game, you can name any color. “That dreamy shade of blue found only in the sky on a perfect afternoon… and in your eyes” is acceptable, but a little weird.

mainBoard.text:
This spell costs {1} more to cast for each ten years you've been alive.
Avatar of Me's power is equal to your height in feet and its toughness is equal to your American shoe size. Round to the nearest ½.
Avatar of Me is the color of your eyes.

mainBoard.flavorText: During the Chicken Revolution, the king managed to keep his head while the others—well, just ran around.
mainBoard.name: Chicken à la King
mainBoard.originalText:
Whenever a 6 is rolled on a six-sided die, put a +1/+1 counter on each Bird. (You may roll dice only when instructed to.)
Tap an untapped Bird you control: Roll a six-sided die. (Like now.)

rulings.text: Chicken à la King can be tapped to activate its last ability. That ability doesn’t use {T}, so any untapped Bird you control will do, even one that entered the battlefield that turn.
Like other Chickens, Chicken à la King has received errata so its creature type is Bird. Additionally, its abilities now refer to Birds.

mainBoard.text:
Whenever a 6 is rolled on a six-sided die, put a +1/+1 counter on each Bird. (You may roll dice only when instructed to.)
Tap an untapped Bird you control: Roll a six-sided die. (Like now.)

mainBoard.flavorText: "Just wait till I get my Krark-Clan Ironworks, Genesis Chamber, and Grinding Station. Oh yeah, and a second Myr Retriever."
mainBoard.name: Johnny, Combo Player
mainBoard.originalText: {4}: Search your library for a card, put that card into your hand, then shuffle your library.
mainBoard.text: {4}: Search your library for a card, put that card into your hand, then shuffle.

mainBoard.flavorText: And yea he doth spake: "Let there be Magic."
mainBoard.name: Richard Garfield, Ph.D.
mainBoard.originalText: You may play cards as though they were other cards of your choice with the same mana cost. You can't choose the same card twice. (Mana cost includes color.)

rulings.text: By default, you are limited to cards legal in the format you’re playing. If you’re playing Draft or Sealed Deck, you can name any card available in the format you’re playing. If you’re playing with Unsanctioned decks, anything goes. Discuss with your playgroup if you’d prefer to modify or eliminate these limitations.
Each Richard tracks its own list of played cards. If one leaves the battlefield and another enters, cards previously played under the first Richard are available once again.

If more than one player controls a Richard Garfield, Ph.D., the cards one player plays has no effect on the other players. For example, each player could play Savannah Lions as a Swords to Plowshares this way.
Playing cards as though they were other cards is optional.

Richard Garfield, Ph.D. essentially makes you play a variant of the Magic game called “Mental Magic.” Here’s how the game works. Whenever you cast a spell, you reveal the card to all players and choose any other card (see below for the cards that you can use) that has that card’s mana cost. (Note that color very much does matter.) That spell can then be cast as though it was the chosen card. You aren’t allowed to choose the same card twice.

The same is true if Richard Garfield, Ph.D. changes controllers. If you play a Savannah Lions as Swords to Plowshares, then an opponent gains control of Richard Garfield, Ph.D., that player can then do the same.

mainBoard.text: You may play cards as though they were other cards of your choice with the same mana cost. You can't choose the same card twice. (Mana cost includes color.)

mainBoard.flavorText: Save a kill spell to deal with this guy.
mainBoard.name: Carnivorous Death-Parrot
mainBoard.originalText:
Flying
At the beginning of your upkeep, sacrifice Carnivorous Death-Parrot unless you say its flavor text.

rulings.text: You must say the flavor text out loud or use a comparable method of communicating. For example, sign language is allowed, but if you sign the flavor text, you are considered to have spoken. Goblin Mime will notice.

mainBoard.text:
Flying
At the beginning of your upkeep, sacrifice Carnivorous Death-Parrot unless you say its flavor text.

mainBoard.name: Cheatyface
mainBoard.originalText:
If Cheatyface is in your hand, you may sneak Cheatyface onto the battlefield. If an opponent catches you right away, that player may exile Cheatyface.
Flying

rulings.text: Cheatyface’s mana cost is {U}{U}{U}.
You must legally get Cheatyface into your hand before you can attempt to sneak it onto the battlefield. For example, you can’t sneak it in from your sideboard or collection during a game.

mainBoard.text:
If Cheatyface is in your hand, you may sneak Cheatyface onto the battlefield. If an opponent catches you right away, that player may exile Cheatyface.
Flying

mainBoard.name: Mer Man
mainBoard.originalText:
When this creature enters the battlefield,
you may draw a card.

rulings.text: Host creatures each have an ability that triggers when it enters the battlefield. It functions like any other creature.

mainBoard.text: When this creature enters, you may draw a card.

mainBoard.flavorText: Many take the lobster for granite.
mainBoard.name: Rock Lobster
mainBoard.originalText: Creatures named Scissors Lizard can't attack or block.
mainBoard.text: Creatures named Scissors Lizard can't attack or block.

mainBoard.flavorText: "You need a six? All right everyone, she needs a six!"
mainBoard.name: Wall of Fortune
mainBoard.originalText:
Defender
You may tap an untapped Wall you control to have any player reroll a die that player rolled.

rulings.text: If a player rolls a die, you can tap an untapped Wall you control to have that player reroll that die. Then, if you didn’t like that result, you can tap another untapped Wall you control in order to have them reroll again.
The Wall you tap to use Wall of Fortune’s ability can be one that came under your control this turn. This includes Wall of Fortune itself.
You can use Wall of Fortune to have a player reroll any die, including the planar die or the d20 from Sword of Dungeons & Dragons.
You decide whether to use Wall of Fortune’s ability right after you see the result of the die roll.

mainBoard.text:
Defender
You may tap an untapped Wall you control to have any player reroll a die that player rolled.

mainBoard.flavorText: Anyone other than a goblin would've gotten only a hand caught in the cookie jar.
mainBoard.name: Time Out
mainBoard.originalText: Roll a six-sided die. Put target nonland permanent into its owner's library just beneath the top X cards of that library, where X is the result.
mainBoard.text: Roll a six-sided die. Put target nonland permanent into its owner's library just beneath the top X cards of that library, where X is the result.

mainBoard.name: Common Courtesy
mainBoard.originalText:
Whenever a player casts a spell without asking your permission while casting it, counter that spell.
When a player asks you permission to cast a spell and you refuse, counter that spell and sacrifice Common Courtesy.

rulings.text: You do have to ask yourself permission to cast spells, although you can give yourself a one-time permission that applies to all future spells you cast.

mainBoard.text:
Whenever a player casts a spell without asking your permission while casting it, counter that spell.
When a player asks you permission to cast a spell and you refuse, counter that spell and sacrifice Common Courtesy.

mainBoard.name: Magic Word
mainBoard.originalText:
Enchant creature
As Magic Word enters the battlefield, choose a word.
Whisper the chosen word: Tap enchanted creature.
mainBoard.text:
Enchant creature
As Magic Word enters, choose a word.
Whisper the chosen word: Tap enchanted creature.

mainBoard.name: Rings a Bell
mainBoard.originalText:
As Rings a Bell enters the battlefield, choose a word with four or more letters.
After you say the chosen word for the first time each turn, an opponent may ring or imitate a bell within five seconds. When no opponent does, draw a card.

rulings.text: The word can include repeated letters.
The word should be in a language common to all players in the game.
While imitating a bell is sufficient if you’re the opponent, having a real bell with you in case your opponent has Rings a Bell in their deck will net you huge style points.

mainBoard.text:
As Rings a Bell enters, choose a word with four or more letters.
After you say the chosen word for the first time each turn, an opponent may ring or imitate a bell within five seconds. When no opponent does, draw a card.

mainBoard.flavorText: "Here on going is heck the what?"
mainBoard.name: Topsy Turvy
mainBoard.originalText:
The phases of each player's turn are reversed. (The phases are, in reverse order, ending, postcombat main, combat, precombat main, and beginning.)
As long as there are more than two players in the game, the turn order is reversed.

rulings.text: Any even number of Topsy Turvys (Turvies?) will essentially cancel each other out and return the order of phases to their normal order.

Steps within each phase play out as normal. For example, although the beginning phase happens last in a turn, the untap, upkeep, and draw steps happen in their traditional order. (If it were the other way, combat would require psychics to get through.)

mainBoard.text:
The phases of each player's turn are reversed. (The phases are, in reverse order, ending, second main, combat, first main, and beginning.)
As long as there are more than two players in the game, the turn order is reversed.

mainBoard.name: Water Gun Balloon Game
mainBoard.originalText:
As Water Gun Balloon Game enters the battlefield, each player puts a pop counter on "0."
Whenever a player casts a spell, move that player's pop counter up one.
Whenever a player's pop counter hits "5," that player creates a 5/5 pink Giant Teddy Bear creature token and resets all pop counters to "0."

rulings.text: In a game with more than two players, players can use paper and pencil to track where their pop! counter is. That is, the tracker located in Water Gun Balloon Game’s art is fun, but not required to work.
Pink joins gold and every eye color imaginable in the set of colors in silver-bordered Magic games.

The pop! counters are considered to be on the inherent tracker in Water Gun Balloon Game’s art, not on the permanent itself. Those counters can’t be removed or moved to another permanent. Similarly, if you proliferate, you can’t add more pop! counters to Water Gun Balloon Game.

mainBoard.text:
As Water Gun Balloon Game enters, each player puts a pop! counter on "0."
Whenever a player casts a spell, move that player's pop! counter up one.
Whenever a player's pop! counter hits "5," that player creates a 5/5 pink Giant Teddy Bear creature token and resets all pop! counters to "0."

mainBoard.flavorText: In that battleground of a ring, the rules aren't nearly so black and white.
mainBoard.name: Underdome
mainBoard.originalText:
{T}: Add {C}.
{T}: Add one mana of any color. Spend this mana only to pay silver-bordered costs.

rulings.text: The mana produced by Underdome’s last ability can be spent to pay any cost imposed by a silver-bordered card. This includes casting a silver-bordered spell, activating the ability of a silver-bordered card, or paying for abilities like the one Infernal Spawn of Infernal Spawn of Evil has.

mainBoard.text:
{T}: Add {C}.
{T}: Add one mana of any color. Spend this mana only to pay Un-costs.
